CONCLUSION: Violation of P1-1;Pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage - award

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG won the parliamentary elections . CARDINAL . In DATE the ORG made an attempt to change the company ’s CEO by using its PERCENT of the votes . UV , however , opposed the attempt . UV ’s position was supported by ORG , who wrote to the President of GPE informing him that in its view the change of management was contrary to the company ’s ORG and that it would consider withdrawing the lines of credit and that the ORG would do likewise in case of a change of management . CARDINAL . Later , at the ORG meeting of DATE , by making use of its PERCENT of the votes , the ORG unilaterally dismissed ORG chief executive officer .

The grounds relied upon by the ORG were , inter alia , that the documents of incorporation were not in conformity with Government decisions and that the applicant did not have legal capacity to be a partner in the company .

UV contested the ORG ’s action , arguing , inter alia , that it had legal capacity and that , under LAW , companies with foreign investments were not bound by Government decisions but exclusively by laws enacted by ORG . It also argued that in any event there was no prohibition under NORP law on stipulating in ORG of a company that a higher percentage of votes was needed for the election of the management .
